title: Ian Evatt
text:
Ian Ross Evatt (born 19 November 1981) is an English professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> manager and former player. He is the current manager of <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a>.
Evatt began his career as a <a href="Midfielder%20%28association%20football%29">central midfielder</a>, but was later converted to a <a href="Defender%20%28association%20football%29">central defender</a>.
He began his professional career in 1999 at <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a>, and he also played for <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a> (on loan), <a href="Chesterfield%20F.C.">Chesterfield</a> (in two spells), <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a> and <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a>.
As a player, he gained promotion with Blackpool (from League One to the Championship in 2006–07, and from the Championship tier to the Premier League in 2009–10) and with Chesterfield (from League Two to League One, as champions, in 2013–14). As a manager, he won promotion with Barrow (from the National League to League Two in 2019–20) and with Bolton (from League Two to League One in 2020–21).
Early life.
Evatt was born in <a href="Coventry">Coventry</a>, <a href="West%20Midlands%20%28county%29">West Midlands</a>. As a child he supported hometown club <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a>. He attended <a href="Caludon%20Castle%20School">Caludon Castle School</a> for his secondary education.
Playing career.
Derby County.
When he was ten years old, Evatt played for the district side in his hometown and was scouted by <a href="Derby%20County%20F.C.">Derby County</a>. He started with them from the age of 11 years. He signed his first professional contract on his seventeenth birthday in 1998. His first appearance in the Derby team came in the last match of the <a href="2000%E2%80%9301%20in%20English%20football">2000–01 season</a>, on 19 May 2001 at <a href="Pride%20Park%20Stadium">Pride Park</a>, when he replaced <a href="%C3%9E%C3%B3r%C3%B0ur%20Gu%C3%B0j%C3%B3nsson">Þórður Guðjónsson</a> in the 78th minute. In the <a href="2001%E2%80%9302%20in%20English%20football">2001–02 season</a> he spent two months on loan with <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Division Two</a> club <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a>, from 10 August to 10 October 2001, playing in eleven League games. His next appearance for Derby came in April 2002 when he came on for <a href="Rob%20Lee">Rob Lee</a> against <a href="Newcastle%20United%20F.C.">Newcastle United</a>, then on the last day of the <a href="FA%20Premier%20League%202001%E2%80%9302">2001–02 Premier League season</a> he made his full debut against <a href="Sunderland%20A.F.C.">Sunderland</a>, playing the full 90 minutes of a 1–1 draw at the <a href="Stadium%20of%20Light">Stadium of Light</a>. Derby were relegated and the following season, under new manager <a href="John%20Gregory%20%28footballer%29">John Gregory</a>, Evatt was a regular starter in the side.
On 9 September 2002, Evatt scored The Rams' third goal as they beat Division Two club <a href="Mansfield%20Town%20F.C.">Mansfield Town</a> 3–1 in the <a href="Football%20League%20Cup">League Cup</a>. In the following round against <a href="Oldham%20Athletic%20A.F.C.">Oldham Athletic</a>, Evatt found himself having to play in goal when <a href="Mart%20Poom">Mart Poom</a> got sent off.
He started out as a centre-midfielder, before being moved to central defence. Evatt said of the move, "I started off my career in midfield. I played a few games in the Premier League and, as I got bigger, I moved backwards but I enjoyed it. They saw the potential for me to be a better centre-half." Evatt suffered an injury in March 2003. Then, just before <a href="George%20Burley">George Burley</a> was appointed as manager to replace John Gregory, who had been sacked in March, Evatt had to have a double hernia operation and he did not feature much for Derby afterwards.
He made a total of 34 League appearances for The Rams, including some in the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a>, but was released by George Burley at the end of the <a href="2002%E2%80%9303%20in%20English%20football">2002–03 season</a>.
Chesterfield.
Evatt signed for Division Two club <a href="Chesterfield%20F.C.">Chesterfield</a> in July 2003, with "Spireites" manager <a href="Roy%20McFarland">Roy McFarland</a> saying that Evatt was his number-one target to take to the club. Initially he played in midfield, where he struggled, before being moved by McFarland into central defence, where his performances improved. He went on to become the club captain and he won the Player of the Season award for the <a href="2003%E2%80%9304%20in%20English%20football">2003–04 season</a>. However, in the summer he needed a further hernia operation as the operation the previous year while he was with Derby did not fix the problem.
On 26 August 2004, Evatt signed a contract extension with the club to the summer of 2007, saying that it took him just five minutes to make the decision to sign, as he felt the club were "going in the right direction". In February 2005, Chesterfield turned down an offer for Evatt from <a href="Bristol%20City%20F.C.">Bristol City</a>. He was also attracting interest from other clubs, including <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a>.
At the end of the <a href="2004%E2%80%9305%20in%20English%20football">2004–05 season</a>, Evatt won the SIFA Player of the Season Award and was runner-up in the CFSS Player of the Season Award. He made a total of 84 League appearances, scoring nine goals for "the Spireites".
Queens Park Rangers.
On 2 June 2005, Evatt signed a three-year contract with <a href="Football%20League%20Championship">Championship</a> club <a href="Queens%20Park%20Rangers%20F.C.">Queens Park Rangers</a> for a fee of £150,000, under a clause in his contract at Chesterfield that allowed him to move if a six-figure bid was made. On 3 December 2005, during an away match against <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke City</a> at the <a href="Britannia%20Stadium">Britannia Stadium</a>, Evatt was assaulted by a Stoke fan. When a Stoke City player was sent off, resulting in a penalty being awarded to QPR, a young "Potters" fan ran onto the pitch and jumped at Evatt from behind, knocking him to the floor, where he was also alleged to have punched Evatt. The youth was arrested and subsequently charged with assault. He was banned from attending football matches for three years and at trial pleaded guilty to assault.
Evatt made 27 League appearances for "the Hoops". On 1 August 2006 he was sent on a six-month loan to <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.">Blackpool</a>, who were then in <a href="Football%20League%20One">League One</a>. He made 26 appearances for the <a href="Bloomfield%20Road">Bloomfield Road</a> club.
Blackpool.
QPR terminated Evatt's contract, enabling him to join Blackpool on a permanent basis on 5 January 2007, during the <a href="transfer%20window">transfer window</a>. He signed an 18-month contract, with the League One club having an option for a further year.
Evatt scored his first goal for "the Seasiders" in the fourth round of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a> against <a href="Norwich%20City%20F.C.">Norwich City</a> on 27 January 2007. His equaliser took the tie to a replay at <a href="Carrow%20Road">Carrow Road</a>.
On 19 March 2007, Evatt was named in the <a href="Press%20Association">Press Association</a>'s <a href="Football%20League%20One">League One</a> "Team of the Week". In May 2007 he was part of the Blackpool team that won promotion to the Championship in the <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.%20season%202006-07%23Play-offs">2006–07 Play-Off Final</a> at <a href="Wembley%20Stadium">Wembley Stadium</a>.
After two-and-a-half months out with a medial knee ligament injury Evatt returned to action on 8 December 2007, as a 65th-minute substitute for <a href="Michael%20Jackson%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201973%29">Michael Jackson</a> in the <a href="West%20Lancashire%20derby">West Lancashire derby</a> against <a href="Preston%20North%20End%20F.C.">Preston North End</a>. However, he was out of action again in early 2008 when he suffered back and hamstring injuries.
Evatt scored his first League goal for Blackpool on 25 October 2008 at <a href="Bloomfield%20Road">Bloomfield Road</a> when he headed their second equaliser in a 2–2 draw with <a href="Crystal%20Palace%20F.C.">Crystal Palace</a>.
He made his 100th League appearance for Blackpool on 24 January 2009, in a 2–0 victory over <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham City</a> at Bloomfield Road. On 2 April 2009, Evatt signed a new two-year contract with Blackpool, with an option for a further year.
Evatt scored his second League goal for "the Seasiders" on 15 August 2009 in Blackpool's first home game of the <a href="Blackpool%20F.C.%20season%202009%E2%80%9310">2009–10 season</a>, a 1–1 draw at Bloomfield Road against <a href="Cardiff%20City%20F.C.">Cardiff City</a>. His 300th career appearance was as a 36th-minute substitute in a 0–0 draw with <a href="Swansea%20City%20A.F.C.">Swansea City</a> at the <a href="Liberty%20Stadium">Liberty Stadium</a> on 24 October. He was named in The Championship "Team of the Week" following his performance and goal in Blackpool's 4–1 home win over <a href="Scunthorpe%20United%20F.C.">Scunthorpe United</a> on 7 November.
After Blackpool's promotion to the <a href="Premier%20League">Premier League</a>, he was <a href="sent%20off">sent off</a> half an hour into their second fixture, a 6–0 reversal at <a href="Arsenal%20F.C.">Arsenal</a> on 21 August 2010.
Evatt was named in the "Team of the Week" for week fourteen of the campaign, sharing the centre-back role with <a href="Aston%20Villa">Aston Villa</a>'s <a href="Ciaran%20Clark">Ciaran Clark</a>.
Evatt was Blackpool's only ever-present player in their 38 Premier League matches during the 2010–11 season. This included one substitute appearance against <a href="Aston%20Villa">Aston Villa</a> at <a href="Villa%20Park">Villa Park</a> on 10 November 2010.
After the departure of <a href="Keith%20Southern">Keith Southern</a> to <a href="Huddersfield%20Town%20A.F.C.">Huddersfield Town</a> in July 2012, Evatt inherited the accolade of being Blackpool's longest-serving current player.
Return to Chesterfield.
After his release from Blackpool in June 2013, Evatt re-joined Chesterfield on a two-year contract on 30 July 2013, and was made the club's <a href="Captain%20%28association%20football%29">captain</a>. He scored his first goal in his second spell for the club against <a href="Fleetwood%20Town">Fleetwood Town</a> in the <a href="Football%20League%20Trophy">Football League Trophy</a> Northern Area Final on 4 February 2014.
He was released by Chesterfield at the end of the 2017–18 season.
Coaching career.
Caretaker spell at Chesterfield.
On 23 April 2018, following the departure of <a href="Jack%20Lester">Jack Lester</a>, Evatt was appointed caretaker manager for the remainder of the season, which ended in Chesterfield's relegation to the <a href="National%20League%20%28English%20football%29">National League</a>.
Barrow.
On 15 June 2018, Evatt was unveiled as the new manager of <a href="National%20League%20%28English%20football%29">National League</a> side <a href="Barrow%20A.F.C.">Barrow</a>.
Evatt officially retired from playing after coming on as a forward late in a friendly at home to his former club Blackpool on 20 July 2019. The appearance was prompted by Barrow's social-media manager, who announced that, should their tweet be retweeted one thousand times, Evatt would come on for the last few minutes.
In his second season in charge, Evatt guided Barrow back to the <a href="the%20Football%20League">Football League</a> for the first time in 48 years as champions of the National League. The season was curtailed due to the <a href="COVID-19%20pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a>, with standings based on a points-per-game basis.
Bolton Wanderers.
On 24 June 2020, <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a> made an official approach to Barrow for Evatt to become their head coach, and Barrow demanded £250,000 compensation should he make the move. Two days later, Barrow rejected Bolton's bid for his services, stating it was below the £250,000 they had asked for. On 29 June, Bolton and Barrow agreed on compensation and Bolton began discussing personal terms with Evatt. Evatt's appointment at Bolton was confirmed on 1 July 2020. His first action as Bolton head coach was to give a new contract to recently released <a href="Ali%20Crawford">Ali Crawford</a>, and his first signing was the leading goalscorer of the <a href="2019%E2%80%9320%20EFL%20League%20Two">2019–20 EFL League Two</a> season, <a href="Eoin%20Doyle">Eoin Doyle</a>. His first competitive match as head coach came on 5 September, a 2–1 home defeat against <a href="Bradford%20City%20AFC">Bradford</a> in the first round of the <a href="EFL%20Cup">EFL Cup</a>. Evatt lost his first four competitive matches in charge, the first time this has happened to a Bolton manager/head coach. This had Bolton in their lowest-ever league position in their history, 21st in League Two. After losing the first five matches of the season, his first win came on 3 October against <a href="Harrogate%20Town%20F.C.">Harrogate Town</a>. Bolton's form soon turned around and after winning five matches in a row, Evatt was named <a href="EFL%20League%20Two%20Manager%20of%20the%20Month">EFL League Two Manager of the Month</a> for November 2020. After the departure of <a href="director%20of%20football">director of football</a> Tobias Phoenix on 11 December, Evatt's role was changed from head coach to manager. After five wins and one draw in February 2021, Evatt was named Manager of the Month again for the second time that season. This was followed up the following month with five wins and one draw, which saw him win March's Manager of the Month award as well. Bolton finished the season in third place after a 4–1 win against <a href="Crawley%20Town%20F.C.">Crawley Town</a> on the final day of the season, which was enough to secure automatic promotion to <a href="EFL%20League%20One">League One</a>.
On 28 May 2021, Evatt signed a new three-year contract with the club.
On 14 November 2021, during a charity match in which the Bolton first-team played a match against a team of Bolton legends — the match helping to raise money for the mother of Bolton player <a href="Gethin%20Jones%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201995%29">Gethin Jones</a> who had been diagnosed with <a href="Motor%20neuron%20disease">Motor neuron disease</a> — substitute Evatt brought himself on after half-time and played as a <a href="Striker%20%28association%20football%29">striker</a> for the first-team. The first-team won 7–4, with Evatt scoring a <a href="hat-trick">hat-trick</a>.
Management style.
Evatt prefers to play attacking possession-based football, with his <a href="Barrow%20A.F.C.">Barrow</a> team nicknamed "<a href="FC%20Barcelona">Barrowcelona</a>" due to the attacking football they played. At Barrow he played a 3-4-1-2 <a href="Formation%20%28association%20football%29">formation</a> and used the same system at <a href="Bolton%20Wanderers%20F.C.">Bolton Wanderers</a>. He changed to a 4-2-3-1 formation, with Bolton going from 20th to third and achieving promotion to <a href="EFL%20League%20One">League One</a>. Evatt frequently decides against naming a <a href="Substitute%20%28association%20football%29">substitute</a> <a href="Goalkeeper%20%28association%20football%29">goalkeeper</a> on the bench, preferring to have more attacking options and has had outfield players do goalkeeping training, just in case. Evatt will sometimes bring on attacking players when winning matches rather than defensive players, preferring to score more goals than defend a lead.
